facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 65 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 65 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated April 11, 1956 in Criminal Revision No. 1584 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 11, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1584 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant is a citizen of India and elected member of West Bengal Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a citizen of India and an elected member of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly. He is also a medical practitioner

facts.text: Appellant is a medical practitioner at Ghatal in Midnapore District of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: He is also a medical practitioner at Ghatal in the Midnapore District of West Bengal. In January, 1954, the appellant gave notice

facts.text: In January 1954, appellant gave notice of intention to ask certain questions in the Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: In January, 1954, the appellant gave notice of his intention to ask certain questions in the Assembly. Those questions were disallowed

facts.text: Questions proposed by appellant were disallowed in accordance with rules of procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Those questions were disallowed in accordance with the rules of procedure for the conduct of business of the Assembly.

facts.text: In February 1954, appellant informed that questions disallowed.

anchor.surface_text: In February, 1954, the appellant was informed that the questions proposed by him had been disallowed. The appellant published

facts.text: Appellant published disallowed questions in Janamat issue of February 28, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant published the questions that had been disallowed in a local journal called Janamat, in its issue of February 28, 1955.

facts.text: In July 1955, first respondent filed complaint against appellant and two others.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1955, the first respondent, whose conduct formed the subject-matter of the questions and who was then functioning as a Sub-divisional Magistrate,

facts.text: First respondent was Sub-divisional Magistrate at time of complaint.

anchor.surface_text: filed a complaint against the appellant and two others, the editor, and the printer and publisher respectively of the journal aforesaid.

facts.text: Complaint under s.500 IPC against appellant, s.501 against second and third respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of complaint charged the appellant with an offence under s. 500 of the Indian Penal Code and the second and third accused, who have been cited as respondents 2 and 3 in this Court, under s. 501 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Magistrate overruled appellant's preliminary objection on privilege by order dated October 11, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate by his order dated October II, 1955, overruled the objection and held that the privilege claimed by the accused was not an unqualified one.

facts.text: Magistrate relied on Dr. Suresh Chandra Banerjee v. Punit Goala (1951 55 C.W.N. 745).

anchor.surface_text: He relied on a judgment of the Calcutta High Court in the case of Dr. Suresh Chandra Banerjee v. Punit Goala 1 in support of his conclusion that the first accused before him, not appellant,

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court under Art. 228, dismissed November 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant moved the High Court under Art. 228 of the Constitution for having the case withdrawn to the 1 1951 55 C.W.N. 745. High Court for determination of the constitutional question raised by him by way of defence, but that, application was dismissed by a Bench of the High Court on November 9, 1955,

facts.text: High Court dismissed Criminal Revision No. 1584 of 1955 on April 11, 1956 rejecting absolute privilege claim.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 65 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 11, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1584 of 1955. C. Chatterjee,

facts.text: High Court held questions never asked in House, not part of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge dismissed the application holding that a member of the Legislative Assembly had no absolute privilege in respect of the questions sought to be asked by him, which had been disallowed but he had published them all the same.

facts.text: Publication not under authority of the House.

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out that the questions had never been asked in the House and that, therefore, could not be said to form part of the proceedings of the House. He further held that the publication in the journal at the instance of the appellant could by no

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal from the judgment of the High Court refusing the claim of privilege.

facts.text: Supreme Court ordered stay of further proceedings and expedited hearing on October 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He also obtained stay of further proceedings in the Court of the Magistrate. The hearing of the appeal was ordered to be expedited That order was passed on October 1, 1956,

facts.text: Case heard in Supreme Court four years later on January 16, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C.J.-This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta, dated April 11, 1956,

facts.text: Facts of the case not in doubt or dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of English law precedents (Lord Abingdon, Creevey) shows absolute privilege limited to in-House speech; republication outside attracts liability.

holdings.text: There is no absolute privilege under Article 194 for a member of the Legislative Assembly publishing disallowed questions in the press; only qualified privilege for republication of in-House speeches.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses (2) and (3) of Art.194 do not support absolute privilege for external unauthorised publications; English common law incorporated limits protection.

holdings.text: Provisions of Article 194 do not support liberal construction favouring publication of questions in press for public service.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in the case of M. S. M. Sharma v. Shri Sri Krishna Sinha  1  has considered in great detail those immunities with respect to the publication of a portion of a speech which was directed by the Speaker to be expunged from the proceedings of the House. This Court has held that the publication of such a portion of the proceedings is not within the privilege attaching to the publication of a faithful report of the proceedings of a House of the State Legislature. That case was not concerned with the penal law of the country.

anchor.surface_text: Creeveys case 2 , 1813.-Mr. Creevey, a member of the House of Commons, had made a charge against an individual in the House, and incorrect reports of his speech having appeared in several newspapers, Mr. Creevey sent a correct report to the editor of a newspaper, with a request that he would publish it. Upon an information filed against him, the jury found the defendant guilty of libel, and the Kings Bench refused an application for a new trial See Lord Ellenboroughs judgment in Rex v. Creevey 2

precedents.cited_proposition: member guilty of libel for publishing his own speech or correction outside House
precedents.cited_holding: the jury found the defendant guilty of libel

anchor.surface_text: That was made clear by Cockburn, C.J. in the case of Wason v. Walter  1 . Explaining why the publication of a single speech in the proceedings in the House would not be absolutely privileged, the learned Chief Justice observed- It is to be observed that the analogy between the case of reports of proceedings of courts of justice and those of proceedings in Parliament being complete, all the limitations placed on the one to prevent injustice to individuals will necessarily attach on the other a garbled or partial report, or of detached parts of proceedings, published with intent to injure individuals, will equally be disentitled to protection.

precedents.cited_proposition: no absolute privilege for publication of single speech or partial reports of parliamentary proceedings, analogous to court proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: a garbled or partial report, or of detached parts of proceedings, published with intent to injure individuals, will equally be disentitled to protection
